In [Greek mythology](/wiki/Greek_mythology "Greek mythology"), **Persephone**
([/pərˈsɛfəni/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English");
[Greek](/wiki/Greek_language "Greek language"): Περσεφόνη), also called
**Kore** ([/ˈkɔːriː/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English"); "the
maiden"), is the daughter of [Zeus](/wiki/Zeus "Zeus") and
[Demeter](/wiki/Demeter "Demeter") and is the queen of the
[underworld](/wiki/Greek_underworld "Greek underworld"). [Homer](/wiki/Homer
"Homer") describes her as the formidable, venerable majestic princess of the
underworld, who carries into effect the curses of men upon the souls of the
dead. Persephone was married to [Hades](/wiki/Hades "Hades"), the god of the
underworld.[1] The myth of her abduction represents her function as the
[personification](/wiki/Personification "Personification") of
[vegetation](/wiki/Vegetation "Vegetation"), which shoots forth in
[spring](/wiki/Spring_\(season\) "Spring \(season\)") and withdraws into the
earth after harvest; hence, she is also associated with spring as well as the
fertility of vegetation. Similar myths appear in the [Orient](/wiki/Orient
"Orient"), in the cults of male gods like [Attis](/wiki/Attis "Attis"),
[Adonis](/wiki/Adonis "Adonis"), and [Osiris](/wiki/Osiris "Osiris"),[2] and
in [Minoan](/wiki/Minoan_civilization "Minoan civilization")
[Crete](/wiki/Crete "Crete").

Persephone as a [vegetation goddess](/wiki/Vegetation_deity "Vegetation
deity") and her mother Demeter were the central figures of the [Eleusinian
mysteries](/wiki/Eleusinian_mysteries "Eleusinian mysteries"), which promised
the initiated a more enjoyable prospect after death. In some versions,
Persephone is the mother of [Zeus](/wiki/Zeus "Zeus")'s sons
[Dionysus](/wiki/Dionysus "Dionysus"), [Iacchus](/wiki/Iacchus "Iacchus"), or
[Zagreus](/wiki/Zagreus "Zagreus"). The origins of her cult are uncertain, but
it was based on very old agrarian cults of agricultural communities.

Persephone was commonly worshipped along with Demeter and with the same
mysteries. To her alone were dedicated the mysteries celebrated at Athens in
the month of [Anthesterion](/wiki/Anthesterion "Anthesterion"). In [Classical
Greek art](/wiki/Art_in_ancient_Greece "Art in ancient Greece"), Persephone is
invariably portrayed robed, often carrying a
[sheaf](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/sheaf "wikt:sheaf") of grain. She may
appear as a mystical divinity with a sceptre and a little box, but she was
mostly represented in the process of being carried off by
[Hades](/wiki/Hades_\(mythology\) "Hades \(mythology\)").

In [Roman mythology](/wiki/Roman_mythology "Roman mythology"), she is called
[Proserpina](/wiki/Proserpina "Proserpina"), and her mother,
[Ceres](/wiki/Ceres_\(Roman_mythology\) "Ceres \(Roman mythology\)") and her
father [Jupiter](/wiki/Jupiter\(Mythology\) "Jupiter\(Mythology\)").

section: Name")]

### Etymology[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Persephone&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Etymology")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/DSC00426_-_Statua_cineraria_etrusca_-
_Proserpina-defunta_con_melagrana-_Foto_G._Dall%27Orto.jpg/220px-
DSC00426_-_Statua_cineraria_etrusca_-_Proserpina-defunta_con_melagrana-
_Foto_G._Dall%27Orto.jpg)](/wiki/File:DSC00426_-_Statua_cineraria_etrusca_-
_Proserpina-defunta_con_melagrana-_Foto_G._Dall%27Orto.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:DSC00426_-_Statua_cineraria_etrusca_-_Proserpina-
defunta_con_melagrana-_Foto_G._Dall%27Orto.jpg "Enlarge")

Persephone or "the deceased woman" holding a [pomegranate](/wiki/Pomegranate
"Pomegranate"). Etruscan terracotta cinerary statue. National archaeological
museum in [Palermo](/wiki/Palermo "Palermo"), Italy

In a [Linear B](/wiki/Linear_B "Linear B") ([Mycenean
Greek](/wiki/Mycenean_Greek "Mycenean Greek")) inscription on a tablet found
at [Pylos](/wiki/Pylos "Pylos") dated 1400–1200 BC, [John
Chadwick](/wiki/John_Chadwick "John Chadwick") reconstructed[n 1] the name of
a goddess _*Preswa_ who could be identified with [Persa](/wiki/Oceanid
"Oceanid"), daughter of [Oceanus](/wiki/Oceanus "Oceanus") and found
speculative the further identification with the first element of
Persephone.[4] [5] _Persephonē_ ([Greek](/wiki/Greek_language "Greek
language"): Περσεφόνη) is her name in the [Ionic Greek](/wiki/Ionic_Greek
"Ionic Greek") of [epic](/wiki/Epic_poetry "Epic poetry") literature. The
Homeric form of her name is _Persephoneia_ (Περσεφονεία,[6] _Persephoneia_).
In other dialects, she was known under variant names: _Persephassa_
(Περσεφάσσα), _Persephatta_ (Περσεφάττα), or simply _Korē_ (Κόρη, "girl,
maiden").[7] [Plato](/wiki/Plato "Plato") calls her _Pherepapha_ (Φερέπαφα) in
his [_Cratylus_](/wiki/Cratylus_\(dialogue\) "Cratylus \(dialogue\)"),
"because she is wise and touches that which is in motion". There are also the
forms _Periphona_ (Πηριφόνα) and _Phersephassa_ (Φερσέφασσα). The existence of
so many different forms shows how difficult it was for the Greeks to pronounce
the word in their own language and suggests that the name may have a [Pre-
Greek](/wiki/Pre-Greek "Pre-Greek") origin.[8]

_Persephatta_ (Περσεφάττα) is considered to mean "female thresher of grain";
the first constituent of the name originates in [Proto-Greek](/wiki/Proto-
Greek "Proto-Greek") "perso-" (related to Sanskrit "parṣa-"), "sheaf of grain"
and the second constituent of the name originates in Proto-Indo European
_*-gʷn-t-ih_ , from the root _*gʷʰen-_ "to strike".[9]

An alternative etymology is from φέρειν φόνον, _pherein phonon_ , "to bring
(or cause) death".[10]

### Roman
Proserpina[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Persephone&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Roman Proserpina")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/Proserpina_kidnapped_Kircheriano_Terme.jpg/220px-
Proserpina_kidnapped_Kircheriano_Terme.jpg)](/wiki/File:Proserpina_kidnapped_Kircheriano_Terme.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Proserpina_kidnapped_Kircheriano_Terme.jpg "Enlarge")

Cinerary altar with tabula representing the rape of
[Proserpina](/wiki/Proserpina "Proserpina"). White marble, Antonine Era, 2nd
century [Rome](/wiki/Rome "Rome"), Baths of Diocletian

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Locri_Pinax_Persephone_Opens_Liknon_Mystikon.jpg/220px-
Locri_Pinax_Persephone_Opens_Liknon_Mystikon.jpg)](/wiki/File:Locri_Pinax_Persephone_Opens_Liknon_Mystikon.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Locri_Pinax_Persephone_Opens_Liknon_Mystikon.jpg "Enlarge")

Persephone opening a _[cista](/wiki/Cista "Cista")_ containing the infant
[Adonis](/wiki/Adonis "Adonis"), on a [pinax](/wiki/Pinax "Pinax") from
[Locri](/wiki/Locri "Locri")

The [Romans](/wiki/Ancient_Rome "Ancient Rome") first heard of her from the
[Aeolian](/wiki/Aeolians "Aeolians") and [Dorian](/wiki/Dorians "Dorians")
cities of [Magna Graecia](/wiki/Magna_Graecia "Magna Graecia"), who used the
dialectal variant _Proserpinē_ (Προσερπίνη). Hence, in [Roman
mythology](/wiki/Roman_mythology "Roman mythology") she was called
[Proserpina](/wiki/Proserpina "Proserpina"), a name erroneously derived by the
Romans from _proserpere_ , "to shoot forth"[11] and as such became an
emblematic figure of the [Renaissance](/wiki/Renaissance "Renaissance").[12]

At [Locri](/wiki/Locri "Locri"), perhaps uniquely, Persephone was the
protector of marriage, a role usually assumed by [Hera](/wiki/Hera "Hera"); in
the iconography of [votive plaques](/wiki/Pinax "Pinax") at Locri, her
abduction and marriage to Hades served as an emblem of the marital state,
children at Locri were dedicated to Proserpina, and maidens about to be wed
brought their _[peplos](/wiki/Peplos "Peplos")_ to be blessed.[13]

### Nestis[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Persephone&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Nestis")]

In a Classical period text ascribed to [Empedocles](/wiki/Empedocles
"Empedocles"), c. 490 – 430 BC,[n 2] describing a correspondence among four
deities and the [classical elements](/wiki/Classical_element "Classical
element"), the name _Nestis_ for water apparently refers to Persephone: "Now
hear the fourfold roots of everything: enlivening Hera, Hades, shining Zeus.
And Nestis, moistening mortal springs with tears."[14]

Of the four deities of Empedocles' elements, it is the name of Persephone
alone that is [taboo](/wiki/Taboo "Taboo")—Nestis is a euphemistic cult
title[n 3]—for she was also the terrible Queen of the Dead, whose name was not
safe to speak aloud, who was [euphemistically](/wiki/Euphemism "Euphemism")
named simply as Kore or "the Maiden", a vestige of her archaic role as the
deity ruling the underworld.

## Titles and
functions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Persephone&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: Titles and functions")]

The epithets of Persephone reveal her double function as
[chthonic](/wiki/Chthonic "Chthonic") and vegetation goddess. The surnames
given to her by the poets refer to her character as Queen of the lower world
and the dead, or her symbolic meaning of the power that shoots forth and
withdraws into the earth. Her common name as a vegetation goddess is Kore, and
in [Arcadia](/wiki/Arcadia "Arcadia") she was worshipped under the title
[Despoina](/wiki/Despoina "Despoina"), "the mistress", a very old chthonic
divinity. [Plutarch](/wiki/Plutarch "Plutarch") identifies her with spring and
[Cicero](/wiki/Cicero "Cicero") calls her the seed of the fruits of the
fields. In the [Eleusinian](/wiki/Eleusinian "Eleusinian") mysteries, her
return is the symbol of immortality and hence she was frequently represented
on sarcophagi.[10]

In the mystical theories of the [Orphics](/wiki/Orphism_\(religion\) "Orphism
\(religion\)") and the [Platonists](/wiki/Plato "Plato"), Kore is described as
the all-pervading goddess of nature[15] who both produces and destroys
everything, and she is therefore mentioned along or identified with other
mystic divinities such as [Isis](/wiki/Isis "Isis"),
[Rhea](/wiki/Rhea_\(mythology\) "Rhea \(mythology\)"),
[Ge](/wiki/Gaia_\(mythology\) "Gaia \(mythology\)"), [Hestia](/wiki/Hestia
"Hestia"), [Pandora](/wiki/Pandora "Pandora"), [Artemis](/wiki/Artemis
"Artemis"), and [Hecate](/wiki/Hecate "Hecate").[16] The Orphic Persephone is
further said to have become by [Zeus](/wiki/Zeus "Zeus") the mother of
[Dionysus](/wiki/Dionysus "Dionysus"), [Iacchus](/wiki/Iacchus "Iacchus"),
[Zagreus](/wiki/Zagreus "Zagreus"),[10] and the little-attested
[Melinoe](/wiki/Melinoe "Melinoe").[17]

### Epithets[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Persephone&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Epithets")]

As a goddess of the underworld, Persephone was given
[euphemistically](/wiki/Euphemistically "Euphemistically") friendly names.[18]
However it is possible that some of them were the names of original goddesses:

  * **[Despoina](/wiki/Despoina "Despoina")** (_dems-potnia_) "the mistress" (literally "the mistress of the house") in [Arcadia](/wiki/Arcadia "Arcadia").
  * **Hagne** , "pure", originally a goddess of the springs in [Messenia](/wiki/Messenia "Messenia").[19]
  * **Melindia** or **Melinoia** (meli, "honey"), as the consort of [Hades](/wiki/Hades "Hades"), in Hermione. (Compare [Hecate](/wiki/Hecate "Hecate"), [Melinoe](/wiki/Melinoe "Melinoe"))[18]
  * **Melivia**[18]
  * **Melitodes**[18]
  * **Aristi cthonia** , "the best [chthonic](/wiki/Chthonic "Chthonic")".[18]
  * **[Praxidike](/wiki/Praxidike "Praxidike")** , the [Orphic](/wiki/Orphic "Orphic") Hymn to Persephone identifies Praxidike as an [epithet](/wiki/Epithet "Epithet") of Persephone: "Praxidike, subterranean queen. The [Eumenides](/wiki/Erinyes "Erinyes")' source [mother], fair-haired, whose frame proceeds from Zeus' ineffable and secret seeds."[20][21]

As a vegetation goddess, she was called:[19][22]

  * **Kore** , "the maiden".
  * **Kore Soteira** , "the savior maiden", in [Megalopolis](/wiki/Megalopolis,_Greece "Megalopolis, Greece").
  * **Neotera** , "the younger", in [Eleusis](/wiki/Eleusis "Eleusis").
  * **Kore of Demeter Hagne** in the [Homeric hymn](/wiki/Homeric_hymn "Homeric hymn").
  * **Kore memagmeni** , "the mixed daughter" (bread).

[Demeter](/wiki/Demeter "Demeter") and her daughter **Persephone** were
usually called:[22][23]

  * **The goddesses** , often distinguished as "the older" and "the younger" in [Eleusis](/wiki/Eleusis "Eleusis").
  * **Demeters** , in [Rhodes](/wiki/Rhodes "Rhodes") and [Sparta](/wiki/Sparta "Sparta")
  * **The thesmophoroi** , "the legislators" in the [Thesmophoria](/wiki/Thesmophoria "Thesmophoria").
  * **The Great Goddesses** , in [Arcadia](/wiki/Arcadia "Arcadia").
  * **The mistresses** in [Arcadia](/wiki/Arcadia "Arcadia").[24]
  * **Karpophoroi** , "the bringers of fruit", in [Tegea](/wiki/Tegea "Tegea") of Arcadia.

## Origins of the
cult[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Persephone&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section:
Origins of the cult")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/P1010629_crop.png/220px-P1010629_crop.png)](/wiki/File:P1010629_crop.png)

[](/wiki/File:P1010629_crop.png "Enlarge")

Gold ring from Isopata tomb, near [Knossos](/wiki/Knossos "Knossos"),
[Crete](/wiki/Crete "Crete"), 1400–1500 BC. Depicted are female figures
dancing among blossoming vegetation; [Heraklion Archaeological
Museum](/wiki/Heraklion_Archaeological_Museum "Heraklion Archaeological
Museum")

The myth of [a goddess being abducted and taken to the
Underworld](/wiki/Rape_of_Persephone "Rape of Persephone") is probably [Pre-
Greek](/wiki/Pre-Greek_substrate "Pre-Greek substrate") in origin. [Samuel
Noah Kramer](/wiki/Samuel_Noah_Kramer "Samuel Noah Kramer"), the renowned
scholar of ancient [Sumer](/wiki/Sumer "Sumer"), has posited that the Greek
story of the abduction of Persephone may be derived from an ancient Sumerian
story in which [Ereshkigal](/wiki/Ereshkigal "Ereshkigal"), the ancient
Sumerian goddess of the Underworld, is abducted by [Kur](/wiki/Kur "Kur"), the
primeval [dragon](/wiki/Dragon "Dragon") of [Sumerian
mythology](/wiki/Sumerian_religion "Sumerian religion"), and forced to become
ruler of the Underworld against her own will.[25]

The location of Persephone's abduction is different in each local cult. The
_[Homeric Hymn to Demeter](/wiki/Homeric_Hymns "Homeric Hymns")_ mentions the
"plain of Nysa".[26] The locations of this probably mythical place may simply
be conventions to show that a magically distant [chthonic](/wiki/Chthonic
"Chthonic") land of myth was intended in the remote past.[27][28]
[Demeter](/wiki/Demeter "Demeter") found and met her daughter in
[Eleusis](/wiki/Eleusis "Eleusis"), and this is the mythical disguise of what
happened in the mysteries.[29]

Persephone is an old [chthonic](/wiki/Chthonic "Chthonic") deity of the
agricultural communities, who received the souls of the dead into the earth,
and acquired powers over the fertility of the soil, over which she reigned.
The earliest depiction of a goddess who may be identified with Persephone
growing out of the ground, is on a plate from the Old-Palace period in
[Phaistos](/wiki/Phaistos "Phaistos"). The goddess has a vegetable-like
appearance, and she is surrounded by dancing girls between blossoming
flowers.[30] A similar representation, where the goddess appears to come down
from the sky, is depicted on the [Minoan](/wiki/Minoan_civilization "Minoan
civilization") ring of Isopata.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Persephone_krater_Antikensammlung_Berlin_1984.40.jpg/220px-
Persephone_krater_Antikensammlung_Berlin_1984.40.jpg)](/wiki/File:Persephone_krater_Antikensammlung_Berlin_1984.40.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Persephone_krater_Antikensammlung_Berlin_1984.40.jpg "Enlarge")

[Rape of Persephone](/wiki/Rape_of_Persephone "Rape of Persephone").
[Hades](/wiki/Hades "Hades") with his horses and **Persephone** (down). An
Apulian red-figure volute krater, c. 340 BC. [Antikensammlung
Berlin](/wiki/Antikensammlung_Berlin "Antikensammlung Berlin")

In some forms [Hades](/wiki/Hades "Hades") appears with his
[chthonic](/wiki/Chthonic "Chthonic") horses. The myth of the rape of Kore was
derived from the idea that [Hades](/wiki/Hades "Hades") catches the souls of
the dead and then carries them with his horses into his kingdom. This idea is
vague in [Homer](/wiki/Homer "Homer"), but appears in later Greek depictions,
and in Greek folklore. "Charos" appears with his horse and carries the dead
into the underworld.[31][32]

The cults of Persephone and [Demeter](/wiki/Demeter "Demeter") in the
[Eleusinian mysteries](/wiki/Eleusinian_mysteries "Eleusinian mysteries") and
in the [Thesmophoria](/wiki/Thesmophoria "Thesmophoria") were based on old
agrarian cults.[33] A lot of ancient beliefs were based on initiation into
jealously-guarded [mysteries](/wiki/Mystery_religions "Mystery religions")
(secret rites) because they offered prospects after death more enjoyable than
the final end at the gloomy space of the Greek [Hades](/wiki/Hades "Hades").
There is evidence that some practices were derived from the religious
practices of the [Mycenaean age](/wiki/Mycenean_Greece "Mycenean
Greece").[34][30] [Kerenyi](/wiki/Karl_Kerenyi "Karl Kerenyi") asserts that
these religious practices were introduced from
[Minoan](/wiki/Minoan_civilization "Minoan civilization") [Crete](/wiki/Crete
"Crete").,[35][36] The idea of immortality which appears in the syncretistic
religions of the [Near East](/wiki/Near_East "Near East") did not exist in the
Eleusinian mysteries at the very beginning.[37][38]

### Near East and Minoan
Crete[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Persephone&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: Near East and Minoan Crete")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Lady_of_Auxerre_Louvre_Ma3098_n2.jpg/220px-
Lady_of_Auxerre_Louvre_Ma3098_n2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Lady_of_Auxerre_Louvre_Ma3098_n2.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Lady_of_Auxerre_Louvre_Ma3098_n2.jpg "Enlarge")

[Lady of Auxerre](/wiki/Lady_of_Auxerre "Lady of Auxerre")
[Louvre](/wiki/Louvre "Louvre")-An Archaic (640 BC) image from
[Crete](/wiki/Crete "Crete"). A version of a Minoan goddess who may be
identified with Kore

In the [Near eastern](/wiki/Near_East "Near East") myth of the early
agricultural societies, every year the fertility goddess bore the "god of the
new year", who then became her lover, and died immediately in order to be
reborn and face the same destiny. Some findings from [Catal
Huyuk](/wiki/Catal_Huyuk "Catal Huyuk") since the Neolithic age, indicate the
worship of the Great Goddess accompanied by a boyish consort, who symbolizes
the annual decay and return of vegetation.[39] Similar cults of resurrected
gods appear in the Near East and [Egypt](/wiki/Egypt "Egypt") in the cults of
[Attis](/wiki/Attis "Attis"), [Adonis](/wiki/Adonis "Adonis") and
[Osiris](/wiki/Osiris "Osiris").[40]

In [Minoan](/wiki/Minoan_civilization "Minoan civilization")
[Crete](/wiki/Crete "Crete"), the "divine child" was related to the female
vegetation divinity [Ariadne](/wiki/Ariadne "Ariadne") who died every
year.[41] The [Minoan](/wiki/Minoan_civilization "Minoan civilization")
religion had its own characteristics. The most peculiar feature of the Minoan
belief in the divine, is the appearance of the goddess from above in the
dance. Dance floors have been discovered in addition to "vaulted tombs", and
it seems that the dance was ecstatic. [Homer](/wiki/Homer "Homer")
memorializes the dance floor which [Daedalus](/wiki/Daedalus "Daedalus") built
for [Ariadne](/wiki/Ariadne "Ariadne") in the remote past.[42] On the gold
ring from Isopata, four women in festal attire are performing a dance between
blossoming flowers. Above a figure apparently floating in the air seems to be
the goddess herself, appearing amid the whirling dance.[43] An image plate
from the first palace of [Phaistos](/wiki/Phaistos "Phaistos"), seems to be
very close to the mythical image of the _Anodos_ (ascent) of Persephone. Two
girls dance between blossoming flowers, on each side of a similar but armless
and legless figure which seems to grow out of the ground. The goddess is
bordered by snake lines which give her a vegetable like appearance She has a
large stylized flower turned over her head. The resemblance with the flower-
picking Persephone and her companions is compelling.[30] The depiction of the
goddess is similar to later images of "Anodos of Pherephata". On the Dresden
vase, Persephone is growing out of the ground, and she is surrounded by the
animal-tailed agricultural gods [Silenoi](/wiki/Seilenos "Seilenos").[44]

[Kerenyi](/wiki/Karl_Kerenyi "Karl Kerenyi") suggests that the name
[Ariadne](/wiki/Ariadne "Ariadne") (derived from ἁγνή, _hagne_ , "pure"), was
an [euphemistical](/wiki/Euphemistical "Euphemistical") name given by the
Greeks to the nameless "Mistress of the [labyrinth](/wiki/Labyrinth
"Labyrinth")" who appears in a [Mycenean Greek](/wiki/Mycenean_Greece
"Mycenean Greece") inscription from [Knossos](/wiki/Knossos "Knossos") in
[Crete](/wiki/Crete "Crete"). The Greeks used to give friendly names to the
deities of the underworld. [Cthonic Zeus](/wiki/Zeus "Zeus") was called
[Eubuleus](/wiki/Eubuleus "Eubuleus"), "the good counselor", and the ferryman
of the river of the underworld [Charon](/wiki/Charon_\(mythology\) "Charon
\(mythology\)"), "glad".[32] [Despoina](/wiki/Despoina "Despoina") and "Hagne"
were probably euphemistic surnames of Persephone, therefore he theorizes that
the cult of Persephone was the continuation of the worship of a
[Minoan](/wiki/Minoan_civilization "Minoan civilization") Great goddess. The
[labyrinth](/wiki/Labyrinth "Labyrinth") was both a winding dance-ground and,
in the Greek view, a prison with the dreaded [Minotaur](/wiki/Minotaur
"Minotaur") at its centre.[45][46] It is possible that some religious
practices, especially the [mysteries](/wiki/Mystery_religions "Mystery
religions"), were transferred from a [Cretan](/wiki/Crete "Crete") priesthood
to [Eleusis](/wiki/Eleusis "Eleusis"), where [Demeter](/wiki/Demeter
"Demeter") brought the [poppy](/wiki/Poppy "Poppy") from [Crete](/wiki/Crete
"Crete").[47] Besides these similarities, [Burkert](/wiki/Walter_Burkert
"Walter Burkert") explains that up to now it is not known to what extent one
can and must differentiate between [Minoan](/wiki/Minoan_civilization "Minoan
civilization") and [Mycenean](/wiki/Mycenea "Mycenea") religion.[48] In the
[Anthesteria](/wiki/Anthesteria "Anthesteria") Dionysos is the "divine child".

### Mycenean Greece[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Persephone&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Mycenean Greece")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/Fresco_of_two_female_charioteers_from_Tiryns_1200_BC.jpg/220px-
Fresco_of_two_female_charioteers_from_Tiryns_1200_BC.jpg)](/wiki/File:Fresco_of_two_female_charioteers_from_Tiryns_1200_BC.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Fresco_of_two_female_charioteers_from_Tiryns_1200_BC.jpg
"Enlarge")

Two women or goddesses on a chariot. Fresco from [Tiryns](/wiki/Tiryns
"Tiryns"), 1200 BC. National Archaeological Museum of [Athens](/wiki/Athens
"Athens").

There is evidence of a cult in [Eleusis](/wiki/Eleusis "Eleusis") from the
Mycenean period;[49] however, there are not sacral finds from this period. The
cult was private and there is no information about it. As well as the names of
some Greek gods in the [Mycenean Greek](/wiki/Mycenean_Greece "Mycenean
Greece") inscriptions, also appear names of goddesses, like "the divine
Mother" (the mother of the gods) or "the Goddess (or priestess) of the winds",
who don't have Mycenean origin .[29] In historical times,
[Demeter](/wiki/Demeter "Demeter") and Kore were usually referred to as "the
goddesses" or "the mistresses" ([Arcadia](/wiki/Arcadia "Arcadia")) in the
mysteries .[50] In the [Mycenean Greek](/wiki/Mycenaean_Greece "Mycenaean
Greece") tablets dated 1400–1200 BC, the "two queens and the king" are
mentioned. [John Chadwick](/wiki/John_Chadwick "John Chadwick") believes that
these were the precursor divinities of [Demeter](/wiki/Demeter "Demeter"),
Persephone and [Poseidon](/wiki/Poseidon "Poseidon").[51][52]

Some information can be obtained from the study of the cult of
[Eileithyia](/wiki/Eileithyia "Eileithyia") at [Crete](/wiki/Crete "Crete"),
and the cult of [Despoina](/wiki/Despoina "Despoina"). In the cave of
[Amnisos](/wiki/Amnisos "Amnisos") at [Crete](/wiki/Crete "Crete"),
[Eileithyia](/wiki/Eileithyia "Eileithyia") is related with the annual birth
of the divine child and she is connected with _Enesidaon_ (The earth shaker),
who is the [chthonic](/wiki/Chthonic "Chthonic") aspect of the god
[Poseidon](/wiki/Poseidon "Poseidon").[53] Persephone was conflated with
Despoina, "the mistress", a chthonic divinity in West-[Arcadia](/wiki/Arcadia
"Arcadia").[36] The [megaron](/wiki/Megaron "Megaron") of Eleusis is quite
similar with the "megaron" of Despoina at [Lycosura](/wiki/Lycosura
"Lycosura").[29] Demeter is united with the god [Poseidon](/wiki/Poseidon
"Poseidon"), and she bears a daughter, the unnameable Despoina.[54] Poseidon
appears as a horse, as it usually happens in Northern European folklore. The
goddess of nature and her companion survived in the Eleusinian cult, where the
following words were uttered "Mighty Potnia bore a great sun".[53] In Eleusis,
in a ritual, one child ("pais") was initiated from the hearth. The name _pais_
(the divine child) appears in the Mycenean inscriptions,[29] and the ritual
indicates the transition from the old funerary practices to the
[Greek](/wiki/Greece "Greece") cremation.[55]

In Greek mythology Nysa is a mythical mountain with an unknown location.[28]
_Nysion_ (or Mysion), the place of the abduction of Persephone was also
probably a mythical place which did not exist on the map, a magically distant
chthonic land of myth which was intended in the remote past.[56]

## Mythology[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Persephone&action=edit&section=10 "Edit
section: Mythology")]

### Abduction myth[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Persephone&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Abduction myth")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Sarcophagus_with_the_Abduction_of_Persephone_by_Hades_%28detail%29.JPG/220px-
Sarcophagus_with_the_Abduction_of_Persephone_by_Hades_%28detail%29.JPG)](/wiki/File:Sarcophagus_with_the_Abduction_of_Persephone_by_Hades_\(detail\).JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Sarcophagus_with_the_Abduction_of_Persephone_by_Hades_\(detail\).JPG
"Enlarge")

[Sarcophagus](/wiki/Sarcophagus "Sarcophagus") with the abduction of
**Persephone**. Walters Art Museum. [Baltimore](/wiki/Baltimore "Baltimore"),
[Maryland](/wiki/Maryland "Maryland")

The story of her abduction by [Hades](/wiki/Hades "Hades") against her will is
traditionally referred to as the [Rape of Persephone](/wiki/Rape_of_Persephone
"Rape of Persephone"). It is mentioned briefly in [Hesiod](/wiki/Hesiod
"Hesiod")'s [Theogony](/wiki/Theogony "Theogony"),[57] and told in
considerable detail in the _[Homeric Hymn to Demeter](/wiki/Homeric_Hymns
"Homeric Hymns")_. Persephone used to live far away from the other gods, a
goddess within Nature herself before the days of planting seeds and nurturing
plants. In the Olympian telling, the gods [Hermes](/wiki/Hermes "Hermes") and
[Apollo](/wiki/Apollo "Apollo") had wooed Persephone; but Demeter rejected all
their gifts and hid her daughter away from the company of the Olympian
gods.[58] [Zeus](/wiki/Zeus "Zeus"), it is said, permitted [Hades](/wiki/Hades
"Hades"), who was in love with the beautiful Persephone, to abduct her as her
mother [Demeter](/wiki/Demeter "Demeter") was not likely to allow her daughter
to go down to Hades. Persephone was gathering flowers with the
[Oceanids](/wiki/Oceanid "Oceanid") along with [Artemis](/wiki/Artemis
"Artemis") and [Athena](/wiki/Athena "Athena")—the _Homeric Hymn_ says—in a
field when [Hades](/wiki/Hades "Hades") came to abduct her, bursting through a
cleft in the earth.[59] [Demeter](/wiki/Demeter "Demeter"), when she found her
daughter had disappeared, searched for her all over the earth with Hecate's
torches. In most versions she forbids the earth to produce, or she neglects
the earth and in the depth of her despair she causes nothing to grow.
[Helios](/wiki/Helios "Helios"), the sun, who sees everything, eventually told
Demeter what had happened and at length she discovered the place of her abode.
Finally, Zeus, pressed by the cries of the hungry people and by the other
deities who also heard their anguish, forced [Hades](/wiki/Hades "Hades") to
return Persephone.[60]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Rape_of_Prosepina_September_2015-3a.jpg/220px-
Rape_of_Prosepina_September_2015-3a.jpg)](/wiki/File:Rape_of_Prosepina_September_2015-3a.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Rape_of_Prosepina_September_2015-3a.jpg "Enlarge")

[The Rape of Proserpina](/wiki/The_Rape_of_Proserpina "The Rape of
Proserpina") by [Gian Lorenzo Bernini](/wiki/Gian_Lorenzo_Bernini "Gian
Lorenzo Bernini") at the [Galleria Borghese](/wiki/Galleria_Borghese "Galleria
Borghese") in Rome.

[Hades](/wiki/Hades_\(mythology\) "Hades \(mythology\)") indeed complied with
the request, but first he tricked her, giving her some
[pomegranate](/wiki/Pomegranate "Pomegranate") seeds to eat. Persephone was
released by [Hermes](/wiki/Hermes "Hermes"), who had been sent to retrieve
her, but because she had tasted food in the underworld, she was obliged to
spend a third of each year (the winter months) there, and the remaining part
of the year with the gods above.[61] With the later writers Ovid and Hyginus,
Persephone's time in the underworld becomes half the year.[62]

Various local traditions place Persephone's abduction in a different location.
The [Sicilians](/wiki/Sicily "Sicily"), among whom her worship was probably
introduced by the Corinthian and Megarian colonists, believed that Hades found
her in the meadows near [Enna](/wiki/Enna "Enna"), and that a well arose on
the spot where he descended with her into the lower world. The
[Cretans](/wiki/Crete "Crete") thought that their own island had been the
scene of the rape, and the [Eleusinians](/wiki/Eleusis "Eleusis") mentioned
the Nysian plain in Boeotia, and said that Persephone had descended with Hades
into the lower world at the entrance of the western [Oceanus](/wiki/Oceanus
"Oceanus"). Later accounts place the rape in [Attica](/wiki/Attica "Attica"),
near [Athens](/wiki/Athens "Athens"), or near [Eleusis](/wiki/Eleusis
"Eleusis").[60]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Frederic_Leighton_-
_The_Return_of_Persephone_%281891%29.jpg/220px-Frederic_Leighton_-
_The_Return_of_Persephone_%281891%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Frederic_Leighton_-
_The_Return_of_Persephone_\(1891\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Frederic_Leighton_-_The_Return_of_Persephone_\(1891\).jpg
"Enlarge")

_The return of Persephone_ , by [Frederic Leighton](/wiki/Frederic_Leighton
"Frederic Leighton") (1891)

The [Homeric](/wiki/Homeric "Homeric") hymn mentions the _Nysion_ (or Mysion)
which was probably a mythical place. The location of this mythical place may
simply be a convention to show that a magically distant
[chthonic](/wiki/Chthonic "Chthonic") land of myth was intended in the remote
past.[22] Before Persephone was abducted by Hades, the shepherd Eumolpus and
the swineherd [Eubuleus](/wiki/Eubuleus "Eubuleus") saw a girl in a black
chariot driven by an invisible driver being carried off into the earth which
had violently opened up. Eubuleus was feeding his pigs at the opening to the
underworld when Persephone was abducted by Plouton. His swine were swallowed
by the earth along with her, and the myth is an etiology for the relation of
pigs with the ancient rites in [Thesmophoria](/wiki/Thesmophoria
"Thesmophoria"),[63] and in [Eleusis](/wiki/Eleusis "Eleusis").

In the hymn, Persephone returns and she is reunited with her mother near
[Eleusis](/wiki/Eleusis "Eleusis"). Demeter as she has been promised
established her mysteries (orgies) when the Eleusinians built for her a temple
near the spring of Callichorus. These were awful mysteries which were not
allowed to be uttered. The uninitiated would spend a miserable existence in
the gloomy space of [Hades](/wiki/Hades "Hades") after death.[n 4]

In some versions, [Ascalaphus](/wiki/Ascalaphus "Ascalaphus") informed the
other deities that Persephone had eaten the pomegranate seeds. When Demeter
and her daughter were reunited, the Earth flourished with vegetation and
color, but for some months each year, when Persephone returned to the
underworld, the earth once again became a barren realm. This is an [origin
story](/wiki/Origin_myth "Origin myth") to explain the seasons.

In an earlier version, [Hecate](/wiki/Hecate "Hecate") rescued Persephone. On
an Attic [red-figured](/wiki/Red-figure_pottery "Red-figure pottery") [bell
krater](/wiki/Krater "Krater") of c. 440 BC in the [Metropolitan Museum of
Art](/wiki/Metropolitan_Museum_of_Art "Metropolitan Museum of Art"),
Persephone is rising as if up stairs from a cleft in the earth, while Hermes
stands aside; Hecate, holding two torches, looks back as she leads her to the
enthroned Demeter.[64]

The 10th-century [Byzantine](/wiki/Byzantine_Empire "Byzantine Empire")
encyclopedia _[Suda](/wiki/Suda "Suda")_ introduces a goddess of a blessed
[afterlife](/wiki/Afterlife "Afterlife") assured to [Orphic
mystery](/wiki/Orphism_\(religion\) "Orphism \(religion\)") initiates. This
[Macaria](/wiki/Macaria "Macaria") is asserted to be the daughter of Hades,
but no mother is mentioned.[65]

### Interpretation of the
myth[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Persephone&action=edit&section=12 "Edit
section: Interpretation of the myth")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Locri_Pinax_Of_Persephone_And_Hades.jpg/220px-
Locri_Pinax_Of_Persephone_And_Hades.jpg)](/wiki/File:Locri_Pinax_Of_Persephone_And_Hades.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Locri_Pinax_Of_Persephone_And_Hades.jpg "Enlarge")

Pinax of Persephone and Hades from Locri. [Reggio
Calabria](/wiki/Reggio_Calabria "Reggio Calabria"), National Museum of Magna
Graecia.

In the myth [Pluto](/wiki/Pluto_\(mythology\) "Pluto \(mythology\)") abducts
Persephone to be his wife and the queen of his realm.[66]
[Pluto](/wiki/Pluto_\(mythology\) "Pluto \(mythology\)") (Πλούτων, _Ploutōn_)
was a name for the ruler of [the underworld](/wiki/Greek_underworld "Greek
underworld"); the god was also known as [Hades](/wiki/Hades "Hades"), a name
for the underworld itself. The name _Pluton_ was conflated with that of
[Ploutos](/wiki/Ploutos "Ploutos") (Πλούτος _Ploutos_ , "wealth"), a god of
wealth, because mineral wealth was found underground, and because
[Pluto](/wiki/Pluto_\(mythology\) "Pluto \(mythology\)") as a
[chthonic](/wiki/Chthonic "Chthonic") god ruled the deep earth that contained
the seeds necessary for a bountiful harvest.[67] _Plouton_ is lord of the
dead, but as Persephone's husband he has serious claims to the powers of
fertility.[68]

In the [Theogony](/wiki/Theogony "Theogony") of [Hesiod](/wiki/Hesiod
"Hesiod"), [Demeter](/wiki/Demeter "Demeter") was united with the hero
[Iasion](/wiki/Iasion "Iasion") in [Crete](/wiki/Crete "Crete") and she bore
[Ploutos](/wiki/Ploutos "Ploutos").[57] This union seems to be a reference to
a [hieros gamos](/wiki/Hieros_gamos "Hieros gamos") (ritual copulation) to
ensure the earth's fertility.[68] This ritual copulation appears in
[Minoan](/wiki/Minoan_civilization "Minoan civilization") [Crete](/wiki/Crete
"Crete"), in many [Near Eastern](/wiki/Near_East "Near East") agricultural
societies, and also in the [Anthesteria](/wiki/Anthesteria "Anthesteria").[n
5]

[Nilsson](/wiki/Martin_P._Nilsson "Martin P. Nilsson") believes that the
original cult of [Ploutos](/wiki/Ploutos "Ploutos") (or
[Pluto](/wiki/Pluto_\(mythology\) "Pluto \(mythology\)")) in
[Eleusis](/wiki/Eleusis "Eleusis") was similar with the
[Minoan](/wiki/Minoan_civilization "Minoan civilization") cult of the "divine
child", who died in order to be reborn. The child was abandoned by his mother
and then it was brought up by the powers of nature. Similar myths appear in
the cults of [Hyakinthos](/wiki/Hyakinthos "Hyakinthos")
([Amyklai](/wiki/Amyklai "Amyklai")), [Erichthonios](/wiki/Erichthonios
"Erichthonios") ([Athens](/wiki/Athens "Athens")), and later in the cult of
[Dionysos](/wiki/Dionysos "Dionysos").[70]

The Greek version of the abduction myth is related to grain – important and
rare in the Greek environment – and the return (ascent) of Persephone was
celebrated at the autumn sowing. [Pluto](/wiki/Pluto_\(mythology\) "Pluto
\(mythology\)") ([Ploutos](/wiki/Ploutos "Ploutos")) represents the wealth of
the grain that was stored in underground silos or ceramic jars (_pithoi_),
during summer months. Similar subterranean _pithoi_ were used in ancient times
for burials and [Pluto](/wiki/Pluto_\(mythology\) "Pluto \(mythology\)") is
fused with [Hades](/wiki/Hades "Hades"), the King of the realm of the dead.
During summer months, the Greek _grain-Maiden_ (Kore) is lying in the grain of
the underground silos in the realm of Hades, and she is fused with Persephone,
the Queen of the Underworld. At the beginning of the autumn, when the seeds of
the old crop are laid on the fields, she ascends and is reunited with her
mother [Demeter](/wiki/Demeter "Demeter"), for at that time the old crop and
the new meet each other. For the initiated, this union was the symbol of the
eternity of human life that flows from the generations which spring from each
other.[71][72]

### Arcadian myths[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Persephone&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Arcadian myths")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Lycosoura-
group.jpg/220px-Lycosoura-group.jpg)](/wiki/File:Lycosoura-group.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Lycosoura-group.jpg "Enlarge")

From L-R, Artemis, Demeter, Veil of Despoina, Anytus, Tritoness from the
throne of [Despoina](/wiki/Despoina "Despoina") at [Lycosura](/wiki/Lycosura
"Lycosura"). [National Archaeological Museum of
Athens](/wiki/National_Archaeological_Museum_of_Athens "National
Archaeological Museum of Athens")

The primitive myths of isolated [Arcadia](/wiki/Arcadia "Arcadia") seem to be
related to the first Greek-speaking people who came from the north-east during
the [bronze age](/wiki/Bronze_age "Bronze age"). [Despoina](/wiki/Despoina
"Despoina") (the mistress), the goddess of the Arcadian mysteries, is the
daughter of Demeter and [Poseidon](/wiki/Poseidon "Poseidon") _Hippios_
(horse), who represents the river spirit of the underworld that appears as a
horse as often happens in northern-European folklore. He pursues the mare-
Demeter and from the union she bears the horse
[Arion](/wiki/Arion_\(mythology\) "Arion \(mythology\)") and a daughter who
originally had the form or the shape of a mare. The two goddesses were not
clearly separated and they were closely connected with the springs and the
animals. They were related with the god of rivers and springs; Poseidon and
especially with [Artemis](/wiki/Artemis "Artemis"), the [Mistress of the
Animals](/wiki/Mistress_of_the_Animals "Mistress of the Animals") who was the
first [nymph](/wiki/Nymph "Nymph").[1] According to the Greek tradition a
hunt-goddess preceded the harvest goddess.[73] In Arcadia,
[Demeter](/wiki/Demeter "Demeter") and Persephone were often called
_Despoinai_ (Δέσποιναι, "the mistresses") in historical times. They are the
two Great Goddesses of the [Arcadian](/wiki/Arcadia "Arcadia") cults, and
evidently they come from a more primitive religion.[22] The Greek god
[Poseidon](/wiki/Poseidon "Poseidon") probably substituted the companion
(_Paredros_ , Πάρεδρος) of the [Minoan](/wiki/Minoan_civilization "Minoan
civilization") [Great goddess](/wiki/Mother_goddess "Mother goddess")[74] in
the Arcadian mysteries.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Throning_goddess_%28Persephone%29_480-460_BC_%28Sk_1761%29_1.JPG/170px-
Throning_goddess_%28Persephone%29_480-460_BC_%28Sk_1761%29_1.JPG)](/wiki/File:Throning_goddess_\(Persephone\)_480-460_BC_\(Sk_1761\)_1.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Throning_goddess_\(Persephone\)_480-460_BC_\(Sk_1761\)_1.JPG
"Enlarge")

Seated goddess, probably Persephone on her throne in the underworld, [Severe
style](/wiki/Severe_style "Severe style") _ca_ 480–60, found at
[Tarentum](/wiki/Taranto "Taranto"), [Magna Graecia](/wiki/Magna_Graecia
"Magna Graecia") ([Pergamon Museum](/wiki/Pergamon_Museum "Pergamon Museum"),
Berlin)

### Queen of the
Underworld[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Persephone&action=edit&section=14 "Edit
section: Queen of the Underworld")]

Persephone held an ancient role as the dread queen of the Underworld, within
which tradition it was forbidden to speak her name. This tradition comes from
her conflation with the very old [chthonic](/wiki/Chthonic "Chthonic")
divinity [Despoina](/wiki/Despoina "Despoina") (the mistress), whose real name
could not be revealed to anyone except those initiated to her mysteries.[54]
As goddess of death she was also called a daughter of [Zeus](/wiki/Zeus
"Zeus") and [Styx](/wiki/Styx "Styx"),[75] the river that formed the boundary
between [Earth](/wiki/Earth "Earth") and the underworld. [Homer](/wiki/Homer
"Homer") describes her as the formidable, venerable majestic queen of the
shades, who carries into effect the curses of men upon the souls of the dead,
along with her husband Hades.[76] In the reformulation of Greek mythology
expressed in the _[Orphic Hymns](/wiki/Orphic_Hymns "Orphic Hymns")_ ,
Dionysus and Melinoe are separately called children of Zeus and
Persephone.[77] Groves sacred to her stood at the western extremity of the
earth on the frontiers of the lower world, which itself was called "house of
Persephone".[78]

Her central myth served as the context for the secret rites of regeneration at
[Eleusis](/wiki/Eleusinian_Mysteries "Eleusinian Mysteries"),[79] which
promised immortality to initiates.

## Cult of
Persephone[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Persephone&action=edit&section=15 "Edit
section: Cult of Persephone")]

Persephone was worshipped along with her mother [Demeter](/wiki/Demeter
"Demeter") and in the same mysteries. Her cults included agrarian magic,
dancing, and rituals. The priests used special vessels and holy symbols, and
the people participated with rhymes. In [Eleusis](/wiki/Eleusis "Eleusis")
there is evidence of sacred laws and other inscriptions.[80]

The Cult of Demeter and the Maiden is found at [Attica](/wiki/Attica
"Attica"), in the main festivals [Thesmophoria](/wiki/Thesmophoria
"Thesmophoria") and [Eleusinian mysteries](/wiki/Eleusinian_mysteries
"Eleusinian mysteries") and in a lot of local cults. These festivals were
almost always celebrated at the autumn sowing, and at full-moon according to
the Greek tradition. In some local cults the feasts were dedicated to Demeter.

### Thesmophoria[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Persephone&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Thesmophoria")]

Main article: [Thesmophoria](/wiki/Thesmophoria "Thesmophoria")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Kore55.jpg/220px-
Kore55.jpg)](/wiki/File:Kore55.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Kore55.jpg "Enlarge")

Kore, daughter of Demeter, celebrated with her mother by the
[Thesmophoriazusae](/wiki/Thesmophoriazusae "Thesmophoriazusae") (women of the
festival). [Acropolis Museum](/wiki/Acropolis_Museum "Acropolis Museum"),
Athens

[Thesmophoria](/wiki/Thesmophoria "Thesmophoria"), were celebrated in
[Athens](/wiki/Athens "Athens"), and the festival was widely spread in Greece.
This was a festival of secret women-only rituals connected with marriage
customs and commemorated the third of the year, in the month
[Pyanepsion](/wiki/Attic_calendar "Attic calendar"), when Kore was abducted
and Demeter abstained from her role as goddess of harvest and growth. The
ceremony involved sinking sacrifices into the earth by night and retrieving
the decaying remains of pigs that had been placed in the _megara_ of Demeter
(trenches and pits or natural clefts in rock), the previous year. These were
placed on altars, mixed with seeds, then planted.[81] Pits rich in organic
matter at Eleusis have been taken as evidence that the Thesmophoria was held
there as well as in other [demes](/wiki/Deme "Deme") of [Attica](/wiki/Attica
"Attica").[82] This agrarian magic was also used in the cult of the earth-
goddesses [potniai](/wiki/Potnia "Potnia") (mistresses) in the
[Cabeirian](/wiki/Cabeiri "Cabeiri"), and in [Knidos](/wiki/Knidos
"Knidos").[83]

The festival was celebrated over three days. The first was the "way up" to the
sacred space, the second, the day of feasting when they ate
[pomegranate](/wiki/Pomegranate "Pomegranate") seeds and the third was a meat
feast in celebration of [Kalligeneia](/wiki/Kalligeneia "Kalligeneia") a
goddess of beautiful birth. [Zeus](/wiki/Zeus "Zeus") penetrated the mysteries
as [Zeus](/wiki/Zeus "Zeus")\- [Eubuleus](/wiki/Eubuleus "Eubuleus")[81] which
is an [euphemistical](/wiki/Euphemistically "Euphemistically") name of
[Hades](/wiki/Hades "Hades") ([Chthonios](/wiki/Chthonic "Chthonic")
[Zeus](/wiki/Zeus "Zeus")).[18] In the original myth which is an etiology for
the ancient rites, Eubuleus was a swineherd who was feeding his pigs at the
opening to the underworld when Persephone was abducted by Plouton. His swine
were swallowed by the earth along with her.[63]

### Eleusinian
mysteries[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Persephone&action=edit&section=17 "Edit
section: Eleusinian mysteries")]

Main article: [Eleusinian mysteries](/wiki/Eleusinian_mysteries "Eleusinian
mysteries")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Eleusis2.jpg/170px-
Eleusis2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Eleusis2.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Eleusis2.jpg "Enlarge")

The [Eleusinian trio](/wiki/Eleusinian_mysteries "Eleusinian mysteries"):
Persephone, [Triptolemus](/wiki/Triptolemus "Triptolemus") and
[Demeter](/wiki/Demeter "Demeter") on a marble bas-relief from
[Eleusis](/wiki/Eleusis "Eleusis"), 440–430 BC. [National Archaeological
Museum of Athens](/wiki/National_Archaeological_Museum_of_Athens "National
Archaeological Museum of Athens")

The [Eleusinian mysteries](/wiki/Eleusinian_mysteries "Eleusinian mysteries")
was a festival celebrated at the autumn sowing in the city of
[Eleusis](/wiki/Eleusis "Eleusis"). Inscriptions refer to "the Goddesses"
accompanied by the agricultural god [Triptolemos](/wiki/Triptolemos
"Triptolemos") (probably son of [Ge](/wiki/Gaia_\(mythology\) "Gaia
\(mythology\)") and [Oceanus](/wiki/Oceanus "Oceanus")),[84] and "the God and
the Goddess" (Persephone and Plouton) accompanied by [Eubuleus](/wiki/Eubuleus
"Eubuleus") who probably led the way back from the underworld.[85] The myth
was represented in a cycle with three phases: the "descent", the "search", and
the "ascent", with contrasted emotions from sorrow to joy which roused the
mystae to exultation. The main theme was the ascent of Persephone and the
reunion with her mother Demeter.[71] The festival activities included dancing,
probably across the Rharian field, where according to the myth the first grain
grew.

At the beginning of the feast, the priests filled two special vessels and
poured them out, the one towards the west, and the other towards the east. The
people looking both to the sky and the earth shouted in a magical rhyme "rain
and conceive". In a ritual, a child was initiated from the hearth (the divine
fire). It was the ritual of the "divine child" who originally was
[Ploutos](/wiki/Ploutos "Ploutos"). In the Homeric hymn the ritual is
connected with the myth of the agricultural god
[Triptolemos](/wiki/Triptolemos "Triptolemos")[55] The high point of the
celebration was "an ear of grain cut in silence", which represented the force
of the new life. The idea of immortality didn't exist in the mysteries at the
beginning, but the initiated believed that they would have a better fate in
the underworld. Death remained a reality, but at the same time a new beginning
like the plant which grows from the buried seed.[29] In the earliest
depictions Persephone is an armless and legless deity, who grows out of the
ground.[30]

Fragment of a marble relief depicting a [Kore](/wiki/Persephone_\(mythology\)

Local cults of Demeter and Kore existed in Greece, [Asia
Minor](/wiki/Asia_Minor "Asia Minor"), [Sicily](/wiki/Sicily "Sicily"), [Magna
Graecia](/wiki/Magna_Graecia "Magna Graecia"), and [Libya](/wiki/Libya
"Libya").

  * **Attica** :[86]
    * [Athens](/wiki/Athens "Athens"), in the [mysteries](/wiki/Mystery_religions "Mystery religions") of [Agrae](/wiki/Agrae "Agrae"). This was a local cult near the river [Ilissos](/wiki/Ilissos "Ilissos"). They were celebrated during spring in the month [Anthesterion](/wiki/Attic_calendar "Attic calendar"). Later they became an obligation for the participants of the "greater" [Eleusinian mysteries](/wiki/Eleusinian_mysteries "Eleusinian mysteries"). There was a temple of Demeter and Kore and an image of [Triptolemos](/wiki/Triptolemos "Triptolemos").[87]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/8/80/Demeter_in_horse_chariot_w_daughter_kore_83d40m_wikiC_Tempio_Y_di_Selinunte_sec_VIa.JPG/220px-
Demeter_in_horse_chariot_w_daughter_kore_83d40m_wikiC_Tempio_Y_di_Selinunte_sec_VIa.JPG)](/wiki/File:Demeter_in_horse_chariot_w_daughter_kore_83d40m_wikiC_Tempio_Y_di_Selinunte_sec_VIa.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Demeter_in_horse_chariot_w_daughter_kore_83d40m_wikiC_Tempio_Y_di_Selinunte_sec_VIa.JPG
"Enlarge")

Demeter drives her horse-drawn chariot containing her daughter Persephone at
[Selinunte](/wiki/Selinunte "Selinunte"), [Sicily](/wiki/Sicily "Sicily") 6th
century BC

  *     * [Piraeus](/wiki/Piraeus "Piraeus"): The _Skirophoria_ , a festival related to the [Thesmophoria](/wiki/Thesmophoria "Thesmophoria").
    * [Megara](/wiki/Megara "Megara"): Cult of Demeter _thesmophoros_ and Kore. The city was named after its _megara_ .[88]
    * [Aegina](/wiki/Aegina "Aegina"): Cult of Demeter _thesmophoros_ and Kore.
    * [Phlya](/w/index.php?title=Phlya&action=edit&redlink=1 "Phlya \(page does not exist\)"), near Koropi, in the [mysteries](/wiki/Mystery_religions "Mystery religions") of Phlya: These have very old roots and were probably originally dedicated to Demeter [Anesidora](/wiki/Pandora "Pandora"), Kore, and [Zeus](/wiki/Zeus "Zeus") Ktesios, who was the god of the underground stored grain. Pausanias mentions a temple of Demeter-Anesidora, Kore [Protogone](/wiki/Greek_primordial_deities "Greek primordial deities"), and Zeus Ktesios. The surname Protogonos, indicates a later [Orphic](/wiki/Orphic "Orphic") influence. It seems that the mysteries were related to the mysteries of [Andania](/wiki/Andania "Andania") in [Messene](/wiki/Messene "Messene").[89]
  * **Boeotia** : 
    * [Thebes](/wiki/Ancient_Thebes_\(Boeotia\) "Ancient Thebes \(Boeotia\)"), which Zeus is said to have given to her as an acknowledgement for a favour she had bestowed upon him.[90] [Pausanias](/wiki/Pausanias_\(geographer\) "Pausanias \(geographer\)") records a grove of [Cabeirian](/wiki/Cabeiri "Cabeiri") Demeter and the Maid, three miles outside the gates of Thebes, where a ritual was performed, so-called on the grounds that Demeter gave it to the [Cabeiri](/wiki/Cabeiri "Cabeiri"), who established it at Thebes. The Thebans told Pausanias that some inhabitants of [Naupactus](/wiki/Naupactus "Naupactus") had performed the same rituals there, and had met with divine vengeance.[91] The Cabeirian mysteries were introduced from [Asia Minor](/wiki/Asia_Minor "Asia Minor") at the end of the archaic period. Nothing is known of the older cult, and it seems that the Cabeiri were originally wine-[daemons](/wiki/Daemon_\(mythology\) "Daemon \(mythology\)"). Inscriptions from the temple in Thebes mention the old one as Cabir, and the new one as son (pais), who are different.[89] According to Pausanias, Pelarge, the daughter of Potnieus, was connected with the cult of Demeter in the Cabeirian ([potniai](/wiki/Potnia "Potnia")).[83]
    * A feast in Boeotia, in the month _Demetrios_ ([Pyanepsion](/wiki/Attic_calendar "Attic calendar")), probably similar with the [Thesmophoria](/wiki/Thesmophoria "Thesmophoria").
    * [Thebes](/wiki/Ancient_Thebes_\(Boeotia\) "Ancient Thebes \(Boeotia\)"): Cult of Demeter and Kore in a feast named [Thesmophoria](/wiki/Thesmophoria "Thesmophoria") but probably different. It was celebrated in the summer month _Bukatios_.[22][92]
  * **Peloponnese** (except Arcadia)[22]
    * **Hermione** : An old cult of Demeter [Chthonia](/wiki/Chthonic "Chthonic"), Kore, and _Klymenos_ ([Hades](/wiki/Hades "Hades")). Cows were pushed into the temple, and then they were killed by four women. It is possible that Hermione was a mythical name, the place of the souls.[18]
    * [Asine](/wiki/Asine "Asine"): Cult of Demeter [Chthonia](/wiki/Chthonic "Chthonic"). The cult seems to be related to the original cult of Demeter in Hermione.[18]
    * [Lakonia](/wiki/Lakonia "Lakonia"): Temple of Demeter _Eleusinia_ near [Taygetos](/wiki/Taygetos "Taygetos"). The feast was named _Eleuhinia_ , and the name was given before the relation of Demeter with the cult of [Eleusis](/wiki/Eleusis "Eleusis").
    * [Lakonia](/wiki/Lakonia "Lakonia") at Aigila: Dedicated to Demeter. Men were excluded.
    * near [Sparta](/wiki/Sparta "Sparta"): Cult of Demeter and Kore, the Demeters (Δαμάτερες, "Damaters"). According to Hesychius, the feast lasted three days (Thesmophoria).
    * [Corinth](/wiki/Corinth "Corinth"): Cult of Demeter, Kore, and Pluton.[18]
    * [Triphylia](/wiki/Triphylia "Triphylia") in [Elis](/wiki/Elis "Elis"): Cult of Demeter, Kore, and Hades.[18]
    * [Pellene](/wiki/Pellene "Pellene"): Dedicated to the _Mysian_ Demeter. Men were excluded. The next day, men and women became naked.
    * [Andania](/wiki/Andania "Andania") in [Messenia](/wiki/Messenia "Messenia") (near the borders of Arcadia): Cult of the Great goddesses, Demeter and _Hagne_. Hagne, a goddess of the spring, was the original deity before Demeter. The temple was built near a spring.
  * **Arcadia**[23]
    * [Pheneos](/wiki/Pheneos "Pheneos") : Mysteries of Demeter _Thesmia_ and Demeter _Eleusinia_. The Eleusinian cult was introduced later. The priest took the _holy book_ from a natural cleft. He used the mask of Demeter _Kidaria_ , and he hit his stick on the earth, in a kind of agrarian magic. An Arcadian dance was named kidaris.
    * **Pallantion** near [Tripoli](/wiki/Tripoli,_Greece "Tripoli, Greece"): Cult of Demeter and Kore.
    * [Karyai](/wiki/Karyai_\(ancient_city\) "Karyai \(ancient city\)"): Cult of Kore and Pluton.[18]
    * [Tegea](/wiki/Tegea "Tegea"): Cult of Demeter and Kore, the _Karpophoroi_ , "Fruit givers".
    * [Megalopolis](/wiki/Megalopolis,_Greece "Megalopolis, Greece"): Cult of the Great goddesses, Demeter and _Kore Sotira_ , "the savior".
    * [Mantineia](/wiki/Mantineia "Mantineia"): Cult of Demeter and Kore in the fest _Koragia_.[93]
    * [Trapezus](/wiki/Trapezus,_Arcadia "Trapezus, Arcadia"): Mysteries of the Great goddesses, Demeter and Kore. The temple was built near a spring, and a fire was burning out of the earth.
    * near [Thelpusa](/wiki/Thelpusa "Thelpusa") in Onkeion: Temple of Demeter Erinys (vengeful) and Demeter Lusia (bathing). In the myth Demeter was united with [Poseidon Hippios](/wiki/Poseidon "Poseidon") (horse) and bore the horse [Arion](/wiki/Arion_\(mythology\) "Arion \(mythology\)") and the unnamed. The name [Despoina](/wiki/Despoina "Despoina") was given in West Arcadia.
    * [Phigalia](/wiki/Phigalia "Phigalia"): Cult of the mare-headed Demeter (black), and [Despoina](/wiki/Despoina "Despoina"). Demeter was depicted in her archaic form, a Medusa type with a horse's head with snaky hair, holding a dove and a dolphin.[94] The temple was built near a spring.
    * [Lycosura](/wiki/Lycosura "Lycosura"),

Main article: [Despoina](/wiki/Despoina "Despoina")

Cult of Demeter and [Despoina](/wiki/Despoina "Despoina"). In the portico of
the temple of Despoina there was a tablet with the inscriptions of the
mysteries. In front of the temple there was an altar to Demeter and another to
Despoine, after which was one of the Great Mother. By the sides stood
[Artemis](/wiki/Artemis "Artemis") and [Anytos](/wiki/Anytos "Anytos"), the
Titan who brought up Despoine. Besides the temple, there was also a hall where
the Arcadians celebrated the mysteries[95][96] A fire was always burning in
front of the temple of [Pan](/wiki/Pan_\(mythology\) "Pan \(mythology\)") (the
goat-god), the god of the wild, shepherds and flocks. In a relief appear
dancing animal-headed women (or with animal-masks) in a procession. Near the
temple have been found terracotta figures with human bodies, and heads of
animals.[23]

  * **Islands**
    * [Paros](/wiki/Paros "Paros"): Cult of Demeter, Kore, and Zeus-Eubuleus.[18]
    * [Amorgos](/wiki/Amorgos "Amorgos"): Cult of Demeter, Kore, and Zeus-Eubuleus.[18]
    * [Delos](/wiki/Delos "Delos"): Cult of Demeter, Kore, and Zeus-Eubuleus. Probably a different feast with the name [Thesmophoria](/wiki/Thesmophoria "Thesmophoria"), celebrated in a summer month (the same month in Thebes). Two big loaves of bread were oferred to the two goddesses. Another feast was named _Megalartia_.[22][92]
    * [Mykonos](/wiki/Mykonos "Mykonos"): Cult of Demeter, Kore, and [Zeus](/wiki/Zeus "Zeus")-Buleus.
    * [Crete](/wiki/Crete "Crete") : Cult of Demeter and Kore, in the month Thesmophorios.
    * [Rhodes](/wiki/Rhodes "Rhodes"): Cult of Demeter and Kore, in the month Thesmophorios. The two goddesses are the Damaters in an inscription from [Lindos](/wiki/Lindos "Lindos")
  * [Asia Minor](/wiki/Asia_Minor "Asia Minor")
    * [Knidos](/wiki/Knidos "Knidos"): Cult of Demeter, Kore, and Pluton.[18] Agrarian magic similar to the one used in [Thesmophoria](/wiki/Thesmophoria "Thesmophoria") and in the cult of the [potniai](/wiki/Potnia "Potnia") ([Cabeirian](/wiki/Cabeiri "Cabeiri")).[22]
    * [Ephesos](/wiki/Ephesos "Ephesos") : Cult of Demeter and Kore, celebrated at night-time.[97]
    * [Priene](/wiki/Priene "Priene"): Cult of Demeter and Kore, similar to the Thesmophoria.[22]
  * [Sicily](/wiki/Sicily "Sicily")

  *     * [Syracuse](/wiki/Syracuse,_Sicily "Syracuse, Sicily"): There was a harvest festival of Demeter and Persephone at Syracuse when the grain was ripe (about May).[98]
    * A fest _Koris katagogi_ , the descent of Persephone into the underworld.[22]
  * [Magna Graecia](/wiki/Magna_Graecia "Magna Graecia")
    * [Epizephyrian Locri](/wiki/Epizephyrian_Locri "Epizephyrian Locri"): A temple associated with childbirth; its treasure was looted by [Pyrrhus](/wiki/Pyrrhus_of_Epirus "Pyrrhus of Epirus").[99]
    * Archaeological finds suggest that worship of Demeter and Persephone was widespread in Sicily and Greek Italy.
  * [Libya](/wiki/Libya "Libya")
    * [Cyrene](/wiki/Cyrene,_Libya "Cyrene, Libya"): Temple of Demeter and Kore[22]

  * [Homer](/wiki/Homer "Homer"):

      * "the gods fulfilled his curse, even Zeus of the nether world and dread Persephone." (9, line 457; A. T. Murray, trans)

    * **Odyssey** : 
      * "And come to the house of Hades and dread Persephone to seek sooth saying of the spirit of Theban Teiresias. To him even in death Persephone has granted reason that ..." (book 10, card 473)
  * [Hymns to](/wiki/Hymn "Hymn") [Demeter](/wiki/Demeter "Demeter")[100]

      * "Mistress Demeter goddess of heaven, which God or mortal man has rapt away Persephone and pierced with sorrow your dear heart?_(hymn 2, card 40)_
    * **Hymn 13** : 
      * "I start to sing for Demeter the lovely-faced goddess, for her and her daughter the most beautiful Persephone. Hail goddess keep this city safe!" (hymn 13, card 1)
  * [Pindar](/wiki/Pindar "Pindar")[100]
    * **Olympian** : 
      * "Now go Echo, to the dark-walled home of Persephone."(book O, poem 14)
    * **Isthmean** : 
      * "Aecus showed them the way to the house of Persephone and nymphs, one of them carrying a ball."(book 1, poem 8)
    * **Nemean** : 
      * "Island which Zeus, the lord of Olympus gave to Persephone;he nodded descent with his flowers hair."(book N, poem 1)
    * **Pythian** : 
      * "You splendor-loving city, most beautiful on earth, home of Persephone. You who inhabit the hill of well-built dwellings."(book P, poem 12)
  * [Aeschylus](/wiki/Aeschylus "Aeschylus")[100]
    * **Libation bearers** : 
      * Electra:"O Persephone, grant us indeed a glorious victory!" (card 479)
  * [Aristophanes](/wiki/Aristophanes "Aristophanes")[100]
    * **Thesmophoriazusae** : 
      * Mnesilochos:"Thou Mistress Demeter, the most valuable friend and thou Persephone, grant that I may be able to offer you!" (card 266)
  * [Euripides](/wiki/Euripides "Euripides")[100]
    * **Alcestis** : 
      * "O you brave and best hail, sitting as attendand Beside's Hades bride Persephone!" (card 741)
    * **Hecuba** : 
      * "It is said that any of the dead that stand beside Persephone, that the Danaids have left the plains to Troy." (card 130)
  * [Bacchylides](/wiki/Bacchylides "Bacchylides")[100]
    * **Epinicians** : 
      * "Flashing thunderbolt went down to the halls of slender-ankled Persephone to bring up into the light of Hades." (book Ep. poem 5)
  * [Vergil](/wiki/Vergil "Vergil")[101]

## Modern
reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Persephone&action=edit&section=20 "Edit
section: Modern reception")]

Main article: [Persephone in popular
culture](/wiki/Persephone_in_popular_culture "Persephone in popular culture")

In 1934, [Igor Stravinsky](/wiki/Igor_Stravinsky "Igor Stravinsky") based his
[melodrama](/wiki/Melodrama "Melodrama")
_[Perséphone](/wiki/Pers%C3%A9phone_\(Stravinsky\) "Perséphone
\(Stravinsky\)")_ on Persephone's story. In 1961, Frederick Ashton of the
Royal Ballet appropriated Stravinsky's score, to choreograph a ballet starring
Svetlana Beriosova as Persephone.

Persephone also appears many times in popular culture. Featured in a variety
of young adult novels such as "Persephone"[102] by Kaitlin Bevis,
"Persephone's Orchard"[103] by Molly Ringle, "The Goddess Test" by Aimee
Carter, "The Goddess Letters" by Carol Orlock, and "Abandon" by Meg Cabot, her
story has also been treated by Suzanne Banay Santo in "Persephone Under the
Earth" in the light of women's spirituality. Here Santo treats the mythic
elements in terms of maternal sacrifice to the burgeoning sexuality of an
adolescent daughter. Accompanied by the classic, sensual paintings of Frederic
Lord Leighton and William-Adolphe Bouguereau, Santo portrays Persephone not as
a victim but as a woman in quest of sexual depth and power, transcending the
role of daughter, though ultimately returning to it as an awakened Queen.[104]

qa.question: in greek mythology who was the goddess of spring growth
qa.answer: ['Persephone (/pərˈsɛfəni/; Greek: Περσεφόνη), also called Kore (/ˈkɔːriː/; "the maiden")']
